Style etc.

TJS2 is a language that follows the lineage of the C language in terms of style. Unlike BASIC or similar languages where a single statement ends with a line break, the writing style is basically "free style."

However, unlike JavaScript, you cannot end a statement simply with a line break.

Free Style

Characters generally referred to as "whitespace," such as line breaks, spaces, and tabs, can be inserted anywhere as long as the meaning does not become ambiguous. Conversely, they must be inserted appropriately so that the meaning remains clear.

Example:
(1)
    function func(a,b) { a++; return a+b; }

(2)
    function func(a,b) {
        a++;
        return a+b;
    }

(3)
    function func(a,b)
    {
        a++;
        return a+b;
    }

(4)
    function
    func
    (
    a
    ,
    b
    )
    {
    a
    ++
    ;
    return
    a
    +
    b
    ;
    }

(5)
    functionfunc(a,b){a++;returna+b;}

(6)
    f unction fu nc(a,b)
    {
        a+ +;

    ret urn a+b;
    }

Among these, (1) through (4) all have the same meaning. However, (2) or (3) is recommended from the standpoint of readability.
In (5), the code is written without any spaces, but doing this causes the characters to run together, and it will not be interpreted correctly.
In (6), spaces are inserted where they should not be, which results in an error.

Comments

Sections enclosed between /* and */ are treated as comments and are not interpreted. Comments can be nested.
Similarly, the portion of a line from // onwards is also treated as a comment.


Example:
    function example(a,b,c)
    {
        return a*b/c; // returns a*b/c
    }

    /*
        Comments can also be written like this
        /* Nesting of comments is possible */
    */
